text:
As customers get more familiar
with Amazon Web Services

(AWS) and embrace the capabilities
that over 200 services can bring

to their business, teams are
actually available to innovate

at the pace of a rapidly
changing business environment.

That innovation is especially
impactful when it is driven
by security teams.

Some of the most common questions
I get from chief information

security officers(CISOs)
include: How does a particular

security service help me meet
a security risk or compliance
objective?

Another common one is: How do
I integrate an AWS security

service into my existing
portfolio of security tools?

In these conversations,
I encourage CISOs to think

broadly and focus on security
outcomes rather than specific

security products or tools. Those
conversations get very interesting

when I propose that most AWS
services, not just the ones

that are marketed as security
services, can be used to drive

security risk or compliance
outcomes.

In many cases, an AWS security
service can be used alone or in

conjunction with one or more
services by customers to achieve

a security-risk or compliance
objective.

Let's take a look at a real-life
example from AWS customer
Goldman Sachs.

In their effort to focus on least
privileged, just-in-time

access for administrative
activities and a supporting

audit trail, they looked to AWS
for a corresponding
service.

Unfortunately, there wasn't
a service that did all those
things in one neat package.

But by combining a couple
of security services, along

with several nonsecurity
services like Amazon DynamoDB,

AWS Lambda, Amazon Athena,
and others, they built their
own solution to solve the problem.

It not only solved the specific
problem for Goldman Sachs

but also demonstrated
what's possible when you focus

on the security outcome first
and the tools second.
